text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Interior minister says no plans to change number of seats in parliament ahead of elections scheduled to be held by November. No plans to reduce voting age to 18 from 19, and new electoral districts to be fixed by mid-April.
- Unions and opposition parties call for Arab summit to revive Arab League decisions on possible freezing of ties with Israel.
- Arab Bank says planning bonus share issue which will double capital to 88 million dinars ($124.3 million).
- King Hussein to meet U.N. Secretary-General on Monday.
- Doctors agree increase in pension to 180 dinars a month.
- Information Minister says government shareholdings in state newspapers will not exceed 30 percent by May 17.

- Marwan Awad, finance minister dismissed in cabinet reshuffle this month, says Jordan's trade deficit still weighing heavily on current account. Export performance and international competitivity is needed for Jordan's economic success.
- King to meet Kofi Annan and receive Seeds of Peace Award on Monday.
- Three-member military committee investigating killing of seven Israeli schoolgirls concludes investigations, plans to refer case to military courts.
